content.question: A metal sphere is hung vertically from the bottom of a spring, and the top end of the spring is attached to the ceiling inside a car. When the car is stationary, the frequency of oscillation for the sphere-spring system is <math alttext="f sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>f</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>. How does the oscillation frequency change, if at all, when the car starts moving forward along a horizontal road with a constant acceleration? Assume the frequency is measured by an observer at rest with respect to the road in both situations.

choices.label: It remains constant at <math alttext="f sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>f</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> while the car is accelerating.
It becomes lower than <math alttext="f sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>f</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> and is constant while the car is accelerating.
It becomes higher than <math alttext="f sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>f</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> and is constant while the car is accelerating.
It increases steadily from the initial frequency <math alttext="f sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>f</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> while the car is accelerating.

content.answer: It remains constant at <math alttext="f sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>f</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> while the car is accelerating.
